title: Brexit: Boris Johnson's bid for new deal vote crushed by Speaker John Bercow
text:

Boris Johnson's bid to put his Brexit deal to a vote again today has been crushed in damning ruling by the House of Commons Speaker.

The Prime Minister made his second attempt in three days to get a 'clean' vote after the first ended in him being voted down - and forced to ask for a Brexit delay.

But John Bercow today scuppered the PM's plans by saying his plan for a new vote went against Commons procedure.

Parliament's rules say MPs can't be given a second vote on the same matter unless the circumstances have changed.

And Speaker Bercow said since there's been little change since 48 hours ago, "the motion will not be debated today as it would be repetitive and disorderly to do so."

Brexiteers voiced fury at the Speaker - who they believe is biased - as Tory Bernard Jenkin sniped: "It’s remarkable how often you please one lot and not the other lot”.

Yet Speaker Bercow was expected to make today's ruling because Mr Johnson's behaviour was widely seen as being outside the rules.

Critics suggested No10 only tried for today's vote in the first place so they could cynically accuse Parliament of thwarting Brexit.

With just 10 days until the UK is due to leave the EU, it leaves the Government's Brexit policy once again in disarray.

But it doesn't in any way mean the Brexit deal is dead. In fact, Speaker Bercow's refusal to hold a vote today makes very little difference.

That is because, whatever happened, Boris Johnson would have had to put a full-blown Act of Parliament allowing Brexit through the Commons before October 31.

That law - the EU Withdrawal Agreement Bill (WAB) - will now enter Parliament tonight and begin debates tomorrow as Boris Johnson tries to rush it through.

(Image: UK PARLIAMENT/AFP via Getty Imag)

The PM was ambushed by opponents on Saturday who demanded he ask for an extension to give MPs time to debate all the Brexit legislation - and make sure the UK cannot crash out in the meantime.

Ministers are instead expected to introduce the EU withdrawal bill today, with MPs getting a vote on its crucial second reading tomorrow.

(Image: UK PARLIAMENT/AFP via Getty Images)

Downing Street believes it has the numbers to get it through.

But the legislation is expected to be altered by MPs, with Labour tabling an amendment calling for Britain to stay in a customs union with the EU.

The amendment would directly undermine the PM's deal which seeks to take the UK out of the customs union so it can strike its own trade deals.

The DUP - whose votes could be crucial - has left open the possibility of backing the amendment although Jim Shannon MP appeared to shoot down those hopes this morning.

(Image: WPA Pool)

Shadow Brexit Secretary Keir Starmer has suggested that Labour would back amendments for a "confirmatory vote" on any Brexit deal, although it is unclear whether the numbers are there in the Commons to get it through.

The EU is prepared to delay Brexit until February if Mr Johnson is unable to get his deal past MPs this week.
description: MPs murmured angrily as the Commons Speaker made a bombshell ruling after Boris Johnson tried to re-run a vote on his Brexit deal
